Comment: Just because I just read. They decided not to review this case based on whether he could deport them under the War Times Act. This was a narrow decision that lifted the pause due to the fact that migrants needed to have their case reviewed in the state in which they are detained. All the justices agreed that due process should absolutely have been applied. I know we're all rolling our eyes but I just want the information out there so accounts don't just throw hyperbole around.

Comment: Just because I read, and understand none of this happens in a vacuum.   You're doing a lot of heavy lifting to pretend that SCOTUS isn't heavily polarized, and normalizing this is people's lives being affected.   "rolling your eyes" over the roll out of deportations of people with no due process?     The administration is deporting people, without due process.  This is people's lives...and, maybe someone you know soon.   The only "hyperbole" here, is anyone failing to understand and apply the gravity of the situation...especially the people he's deporting, and threatening to report.   The Court is helping him break the law...we can play semantics...but, this is people's lives at stake.  >https://apnews.com/article/supreme-court-trump-deportation-salvador-maryland-40136c5aa844b6c12ba20ee67ab4df9a  Homie, you need to read *a lot* more than a paragraph to try and lecture people about the gravity of what these decisions, and actions are in context...and, where it's all going.
